text: This is a download from BBC Learning English.
To find out more, visit our website.
6-Nate English from the BBC.
Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English,
the show that brings you an interesting topic,
authentic listening practice and six new items of vocabulary.
Dan
speaker: Neil

text: And I'm Neil.
And I'm Neil. In this episode we'll be discussing if happiness is genetic
speaker: Neil

text: How happy would you say you are Neil?
speaker: Dan

text: I’m pretty happy I think. Why do you ask?
speaker: Dan

text: Well, in March this year the UN published its fifth world happiness report.
speaker: Dan

text: Is that the one that ranks all the countries based on how happy they are?
Oh, you've heard of it then.
Overall, there are 155 countries included,
and Norway came top of them all, overtaking Denmark,
which was the leader for the year's 2012 to 2016.
Well what about the UK?
speaker: Neil

text: Ah, well, that's this week's question, isn't it?
Where did the UK place?
Is it A in the top 10, B between 11th
c) after 21st
speaker: Neil

text: Well, I’m going to say c) after 21st
speaker: Neil

text: Okay, you know the drill, no answers until the end of the show.
So Norway, eh?
And Denmark the previous year, their neighbours.
Yes, in fact, for the last five years,
the results have been pretty much the same.
Nordic countries tend to dominate the top of the table.
Dominate, meaning control.
Okay, well, how are the results decided?
It's very simple.
It’s very simple. They ask 1000 people in each country a single subjective question.
speaker: subjective

text: Subjective means 'based on personal experience, beliefs or feelings'. …Well, what’s the question?
speaker: Subjective

text: beliefs or feelings.
Well, what's the question?
Imagine a ladder with steps numbered from zero at the bottom
to 10 at the top.
The top of the ladder represents the best possible life for you,
and the bottom of the ladder represents the worst possible life for you.
On which step of the ladder would you say
you personally feel you stand at this time?
That’s actually quite simple.
speaker: Neil

text: Yep. The Nordic countries all score an average close to 7.5 out of 10.
speaker: Dan

text: So we have a number of neighbouring countries
which all claim to be extremely happy.
There must be a connection.
Is it the weather?
Well, that's a logical conclusion,
but there is another idea.
Well, that’s a logical conclusion, but there is another idea. I’ll let Professor Andrew Oswald from the University of Warwick explain.
speaker: Dan

text: We think that there's a genetic component in part
to why the Danes do so well,
coming so regularly at the head of happiness,
international league tables.
It does appear from the data that the Danes have
the smallest amount of the, you might say,
dangerous, short kind of genetic pattern.
So they may have a kind of inoculation against the possibility of depression.
So Professor Oswald mentioned there's a genetic component
or part to Danish DNA,
which gives them an inoculation
or illness protection against depression and sadness.
Yep. All of the Nordic countries have a similar make-up.
speaker: Dan

text: But he said ‘in part’. That means it doesn’t explain everything. So, there’s something missing.
speaker: Neil

text: So there's something missing.
There's no fooling you.
There’s no fooling you! Michael Booth has written a book about Nordic happiness. He has another theory.
speaker: Dan

text: He has another theory.
There are so many reasons why the Danes are happy,
why they're content,
that have nothing to do with DNA.
Of course they're happy.
They're rich, they're sexy, they're funny,
they don't work that much.
So being rich, funny, sexy and not working much
is why they're content, meaning satisfied.
That sounds a bit like you, Dan.
Oh, I can't publicly comment on that,
me, and I'm sorry,
but there is one more piece that we're missing.
Hugga.
It's a lone word,
and it only just appeared in the British dictionaries.
We don't have a direct translation,
but it basically means cosiness.
Cosiness, meaning 'warm, comfortable and safe'.
speaker: Neil

text: Yes, Danes love simple comforts.
A warm, cozy room,
some drinks, some candles, a fire,
and they're happy.
Maybe that's the secret.
Well, the secret to my happiness right now
is finding out if I was right in the quiz.
Oh, yes.
I asked,
where did the UK place
in the World Happiness Report 2017?
a) in the top 10
speaker: Neil

text: b) between 11th and 20th
speaker: Neil

text: c) after 21st
speaker: Dan

text: I said c) after 21st
speaker: Neil

text: And I'm afraid you're wrong, my friend.
b) between 11th and 20th
speaker: Dan

text: We were actually 19th.
Well, let’s make our listeners happy by going through the vocabulary.
speaker: Neil

text: by going through the vocabulary.
Okay.
First, we had dominate.
If you dominate something or someone,
you control it.
It's quite an aggressive word.
You wouldn't use it for people much,
but give us an example, Neil.
You can talk about a team dominating play in a sport.
Next, we had subjective.
If something is subjective,
it is based on personal experience,
beliefs or feelings,
rather than facts,
which are objective.
What type of things are subjective, Dan?
Oh, it's our opinions of art,
music, jokes, food.
Oh, you know, I like sausages and ice cream,
but no one else does.
Yes, because it's disgusting.
Then we had component.
A component is part of something
that makes up a larger whole.
Television's and computers have many components in them.
And a person can be an essential component
in a team like a goalkeeper in football.
After that was inoculation.
An inoculation is a form of disease protection.
It is a synonym of Dan.
Vaccination.
I went on holiday last year
and I had to have my inoculations updated.
Then we had content.
If you are content, you are satisfied and want nothing.
What makes you content, Neil?
Oh, a warm, sunny day in my garden with a good book.
And finally we had cosiness.
Cosiness comes from cosy, which means warm, comfortable and safe.
Where's cosy for you, Dan?
Oh, that's easy.
On a freezing cold day,
it's tucked up in bed with a nice cup of tea.
And that's the end of today's 6 Minute English.
Please join us again soon.
And we're on social media too, of course.
Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and YouTube.
See you there.
Bye!
